__data__.text: Brimble was born in Molteno, South Africa in 1910 to an English father and Bantu mother who was a nurse. His father, a railways electrician, had moved to South Africa from Bristol and married Brimble's mother after she nursed him back to health from Boer War injuries. They had five sons and left South Africa in 1912 due to apartheid, first moving to Australia, but then to Hawaii in 1913 due to restrictive white settlement laws. Their sixth son, Wilfred, was born in Hawaii in November 1913.

The Brimble family, including Harold, his Bantu wife Jane, and their five sons, relocated from South Africa to Australia and then Hawaii due to apartheid. In Hawaii, they had another son, Wilfred, in 1913. Later, they moved to Auckland, New Zealand, in 1915, aboard the S.S Niagara, with Harold identified as a salesman, Jane as a housewife, and the boys as students. The family, consisting of Harold, John, Cyril, Ted, Lionel, Walter, Jane, and Wilfred, settled in Onehunga, Auckland. Their nationalities were English, African, and American, with Wilfred being the only American due to his Hawaiian birth. Both Walter and Wilfred would later represent New Zealand in rugby league.

Upon settling in Auckland's Onehunga suburb, the Brimble family welcomed a seventh son, Amyas, on April 4, 1917. Sadly, both Amyas and Harold passed away during the Spanish Flu Epidemic, with Harold dying in November 1917 and Amyas in May 1920. The Brimble brothers, including John, Cyril, and Ted, were involved in rugby and rugby league. The Manukau Rugby club, where they played, was originally located in Onehunga before moving to Māngere. Their home field was Waikaraka Park. The earliest record of Brimble in Auckland newspapers was on January 28, 1924, in the Auckland Star, but it referred to swimming, not rugby league.

The Brimble family, residing in Auckland's Onehunga suburb, had sons who participated in swimming and rugby. Amyas, the seventh son, was born in 1917 and died in 1920 due to the Spanish Flu. He was recognized for placing third in a 50-yard juvenile race at the Basin Reserve, although not for rugby league. In 1924, another Brimble brother attended Eden Park to assist in selecting an Auckland Primary Schools representative side. In 1925, John played for the Manukau Rovers rugby club's senior side, while two other brothers, likely Cyril and Ted, played in lower grades. That year, John was chosen for the Auckland B team. In 1927, Ted received a medal for being the most improved third-grade player at the club's annual ball.

In 1927, Cliff Satherley won the senior award and later switched to rugby league, representing New Zealand. Walter received the seventh-grade award and played in the third grade with Cyril. John continued in the senior side and was selected for the Auckland A team, playing against Bay of Plenty. This marked his first senior representative match, followed by four other brothers. Ted made his debut for the Manukau senior side, which included Cyril, in a match against Tramways. They won the game with their third-grade intermediate side, as only six senior players were present. This indicates that multiple Brimble brothers were actively participating and excelling in rugby at various levels during this time.

In 1927, due to the absence of several senior players (including John, who was playing for the Auckland team), Cyril and Ted Brimble filled in and played with the third-grade intermediate side against Tramways. The Auckland Star praised Cyril's performance and noted that Ted, known as "Arab," impressed the crowd with his individual play. By 1929, Ted had become a regular in the senior side, which had moved up to the top division. He made his debut as a five-eighth in their opening round match against City, where they won with Ted scoring a drop goal and John contributing a try. Notably, Karl Ifwersen, a former All Black and New Zealand rugby league international, played for City. This suggests that multiple Brimble brothers were actively participating and excelling in rugby at various levels during this time.

In 1929, both Ted "Arab" Brimble and Karl Ifwersen, an ex-All Black and New Zealand rugby league international, were playing for different teams – Ted for Manukau and Ifwersen for City. Ted, only 18 years old, had become a regular in the senior side and was excelling as a five-eighth. He made an impressive debut in the top division against City, scoring a drop goal, with John also contributing a try in their victory. The following week, Ted's crucial drop goal against Marist helped Manukau win the match 8-6 after trailing 6-5. Newspapers praised Ted's performance, highlighting his skill, defensive brilliance, and potential as a five-eighth, despite a few fumbled passes.

In the 1929 season, Ted "Arab" Brimble, an 18-year-old five-eighth, had some mishandled passes but compensated with standout plays, such as scoring a difficult drop goal surrounded by opponents. His lightweight frame didn't hold him back from taking on larger forwards. Playing at Eden Park, the team faced losses against Ponsonby (29-17) and Training College (25-11), despite Ted's efforts. He contributed two tries in the latter game, including a notable Manukau attack that moved from one end of the field to the other. Critics praised Ted's early strong running but pointed out his occasional failure to distribute the ball promptly.

In the 1929 season, Ted "Arab" Brimble, an 18-year-old five-eighth, showcased his skills through impressive tries and strong running, despite his slighter build. He scored two tries in the match against Training College, one following a length-of-the-field Manukau attack and another from a scrum near the line. He also contributed a try in the games against University and Technical Old Boys. Critics acknowledged his defensive abilities, highlighting his sound performance and low tackles. However, they also noted his occasional delay in distributing the ball. Despite Ted's efforts, the team faced losses at Eden Park against Ponsonby and Training College.

In the 1929 season, Ted "Arab" Brimble, an 18-year-old five-eighth, consistently performed well, contributing tries and strong defensive plays, although he sometimes hesitated to distribute the ball. The team faced losses at Eden Park but had wins against Technical Old Boys and a draw with Grammar Old Boys. Brimble's defensive skills were highlighted in these matches, with critics praising his low tackles. However, there was less focus on him after he helped Manukau secure a victory over North Shore in their last game of the season. At the club's end-of-season event, it was mentioned that John had earned Auckland representative honors, while Wilfred and Lionel were recognized for being part of the champion sixth-grade side. The 1930 season marked Brimble's final year playing rugby union.

At the end of the 1929 season, John received Auckland representative honors, while Wilfred and Lionel were acknowledged for being part of the champion sixth-grade side. In 1930, Ted, also known as Arab Brimble, played six games for Manukau from May until early June. He suffered an injured ankle in a match against an unspecified team but recovered to play in the following game against City at Onehunga. Despite his contribution to an 18–0 win, his performance in a later loss to Ponsonby at Eden Park was criticized, with the Star noting that he was one of the weaker links in Manukau's defense. The 1930 season was Ted's final year playing rugby union.

After playing six games for Manukau in the 1930 rugby union season, Ted, or Arab Brimble, was criticized for his performance in a loss to Ponsonby. He continued to play, contributing in a loss to Technical Old Boys, and ultimately scoring a try in his final victory over Grafton. Soon after, Ted switched to rugby league and joined the Newton Rangers side in the Auckland Rugby League senior grade, likely due to his older brother Cyril already playing there. His first rugby league match was against Marist Old Boys on June 21 at Carlaw Park. The text suggests that Ted's defensive play in rugby union was criticized, but he still managed to score a try in his final game before switching to rugby league.

Following criticism for his defensive play in rugby union, Ted, or Arab Brimble, switched to rugby league and joined the Newton Rangers side, where his older brother Cyril was already playing. In his first match against Marist Old Boys, Ted played in the five eighths position and contributed to a try scored by Allen St George. His absence from the Manukau team was noticeable, and his debut in rugby league received positive reviews, with commentary on his quickness and ability to find openings.

Ted, also known as Arab Brimble, excelled in his new position of five eighths in rugby league, complementing his brother Cyril's performance as center. He scored his first try in rugby league during a match against Ellerslie, contributing to their victory. The Sun praised Ted's impact on Newton's backline. He added another try to his tally in the games that followed, including one in a loss to Devonport United and another in a defeat against City Rovers. Ted successfully converted a try for Newton in their loss to Kingsland Athletic.

After the match against City Rovers, Ted, also known as Arab Brimble, continued to shine in his five eighths position for Newton, contributing to their backline's performance. He scored tries in games against Kingsland Athletic and Devonport United, and successfully converted a try for Ray Middleton against Kingsland Athletic. Despite losses to Kingsland Athletic and Ponsonby, Ted's performance was praised, with the Auckland Star and New Zealand Herald noting his strong play. Newton's losing streak ended with an 11-3 victory over Richmond Rovers, where the Brimble brothers were highlighted for their exceptional play. The draw with Marist in the final round of the 1st grade competition saw Ted once again recognized for his outstanding performance.

Following the match against Marist, Ted Brimble's exceptional performance as a five eighth for Newton is highlighted, with the Sun praising his opportunistic plays and interceptions of opposing team's passes. The newspapers had conflicting reports on the scorer of one try, crediting either Ted or his brother Cyril, but both agreed on Ted's significant contribution to the team's play. Due to their performance, Newton ended the 1930 Monteith Shield competition tied for 5th place. The newspapers also pointed out the weakness in Newton's backs, specifically Cammick, resulting in Ted shouldering much of the responsibility as the first five eighth.

The newspapers praised Ted Brimble's outstanding performance as the first five-eighth for Newton, noting his skillful plays and interceptions, which significantly contributed to the team's performance in the 1930 Monteith Shield competition. Despite Cammick's weakness in the backs, Ted's performance was remarkable, and he was credited with scoring one of Newton's tries. His impressive pace led to two of Newton's tries, and he played a crucial role in counter-attacks. Ted's performance was so impressive that the Star noted that his plays "invariably spelt danger" for the opposing team. Unfortunately, Newton ended the competition tied for 5th place, and Ted's last game for them in his debut season was a 15-2 loss to Devonport United in the first round of the Roope Rooster knockout competition.

After his impressive performance in the Monteith Shield competition, Ted Brimble transferred his skills to the Wednesday league, playing as an inside back for the New Zealand Fertilisers team. His strong defensive play and ability to initiate dangerous counter-attacks continued to be highlighted, as he and Butterworth played prominently in their 5-0 win against Chess Taxis. The following week, Ted, along with Muir and Butterworth, contributed to the team's 9-0 victory over Trotting Trainers, taking advantage of their opponents' mistakes. The absence of assertive wingers to support Ted was again noted, similar to his time with Newton.

Following his success in the Monteith Shield competition, Ted Brimble showcased his skills in the Wednesday league, playing as an inside back for the New Zealand Fertilisers team. He and his teammates, including Muir and Butterworth, consistently capitalized on their opponents' mistakes, resulting in a series of victories for the team. Notably, they secured a 5-0 win against Chess Taxis and a 9-0 victory over Trotting Trainers. Despite the absence of assertive wingers to support Ted, the team continued to perform well.

Meanwhile, Ted also competed in the Ōtorohanga Sports Club's athletic meeting, running in several races. In club rugby league, he played 15 games and scored 5 tries for Newton in the 1931 season. That year, the first grade competition began competing for the Fox Memorial Shield, which is still contested today. After the 1931 season, Ted moved to Christchurch and played senior rugby for Merivale before transferring back to rugby league and joining the Addington club in 1932. He went on to represent the Canterbury side and later, after moving to Wellington, represented Wellington as well.

In the 1931 season, Ted Brimble played 15 games and scored 5 tries for Newton in the club rugby league, which had recently started competing for the inaugural Fox Memorial Shield. However, the team's performance was mediocre, finishing 5th out of 7 teams with a record of 2 wins, 2 draws, and 8 losses. They particularly struggled in attack, managing to score only 83 points in 12 matches, the lowest among all teams. Criticism was directed towards Ted's performance, with the Auckland Star noting his poor handling skills and negative impact on the team's performance.

In the 1931 season, Ted Brimble's performance for Newton in the Fox Memorial Shield competition received mixed reviews. Despite his three tries in the match against Marist, his poor handling skills and mistakes were criticized, and he was blamed for the team's losses to Richmond and Ponsonby. Newton, with a young squad, struggled in attack and had a mediocre record of 2 wins, 2 draws, and 8 losses. Brimble's tries against Marist came from a pass from Francis, outpacing the opposition, and a pass from Beattie. The team had a slight improvement with a draw against City Rovers and a win over Ellerslie-Ōtāhuhu, but lost to both Devonport and Marist, who finished as champions and runners-up.

In the 1931 season, Ted Brimble's performance for Newton was inconsistent, with both positive and negative reviews. While he scored a try in the losses to Devonport (20-5) and Marist (17-9), his poor handling skills and mistakes were criticized, and he was blamed for Newton's losses to Richmond and Ponsonby. Despite this, Brimble was praised for his defensive and attacking skills in the matches against Marist, Ponsonby, and Richmond. Newton, with a young squad, had a mediocre record of 2 wins, 2 draws, and 8 losses. They managed to secure a win over Ellerslie-Ōtāhuhu and City Rovers but lost to both Devonport and Marist, who finished as champions and runners-up. Newton played against Hamilton twice, on August 9 and August 22.

In the 1931 season, Ted Brimble had a mix of positive and negative reviews for his performance in Newton's games, with his defensive and attacking skills being highlighted despite some handling errors. Newton, with a young team, had a mediocre record and lost to both Devonport and Marist, who became champions and runners-up. Brimble's performance was particularly notable in the games against Hamilton, where he contributed to Newton's 28-6 victory despite the absence of 5 regular players. The season ended with a loss to Devonport in the Roope Rooster knockout competition. Brimble's performance in the 1931 season earned him a spot in the 1932 New Zealand team to play against England. He scored 6 tries in 10 matches for Newton, contributing to their competitiveness in most games despite finishing last. In the opening round, Brimble scored a try in Newton's 18-5 win against City.

In the 1931 season, Ted Brimble played a standout role for Newton, contributing to their competitiveness in games despite a young team and a mediocre record. His performance was particularly notable in the games against Hamilton and Devonport. Brimble's skills in attacking and defense were highlighted, even though he made some handling errors. His performance in the season led to his selection in the 1932 New Zealand team to play against England. Brimble scored a try in the 8-8 draw against Devonport and a crucial try in the 15-13 win over Richmond. His exceptional play and quick decision-making were praised by spectators and earned Newton their victory. Brimble's performance was a significant factor in Newton's success in the season.

In the 1931 season, Ted Brimble, the five-eighths player, showcased exceptional skills in attacking and handling, which significantly contributed to Newton's success. His impressive back play and quick decision-making led to several fine movements and victories for the team. Brimble's performance was instrumental in scoring tries, including an early penalty goal, a try in the 8-8 draw against Devonport, and a crucial try in the 15-13 win over Richmond. Despite some handling errors and running across the field, Brimble's performance was highly praised, and he was selected for the 1932 New Zealand team to play against England. His contributions as an inside back were particularly notable in the 13-10 loss to Marist, where he was the best performer.

In the 1931 season, Ted Brimble continued to excel as a five-eighths player, contributing significantly to Newton's success with his attacking skills and quick decision-making. He scored tries in matches against the Herald, City, Ponsonby, and Devonport, showcasing his ability to make openings and create scoring opportunities. Despite occasional handling errors and running across the field, Brimble's performance was consistently praised, leading to his selection for the 1932 New Zealand team. His performance in the 13-10 loss to Marist was particularly notable, where he was the standout player. However, Newton ultimately lost the match against Devonport, who were leading the competition, and later to Richmond. Brimble's contributions as an inside back were instrumental in Newton's offensive plays throughout the season.

In the 9th round of the 1931 season, Ted Brimble scored his fifth try for Newton, who lost the match to Richmond 13-6. Notably, this game marked Bert Cooke's debut in rugby league, having been a prominent All Black in rugby union. Brimble's try came from a "scramble," giving Newton a temporary lead. Due to heavy rain, Newton's final Fox Memorial match was postponed to 13 August, while an Auckland XIII side, including Brimble in the five-eighths position, played against South Auckland (Waikato) on 16 July. A trial match also took place that day, where Brimble featured in the Possibles team.

In the 1931 season, Ted Brimble, a swift player, competed against Bert Cooke for the five-eighths position in the Auckland rugby league team, but Cooke was chosen instead. Brimble played in a trial match on 16 July, where he stood out over Stan Prentice, who later made it into the North Island team. Brimble's side lost the match 26-12, despite his contributions, including a nice run that led to a try and another run where he opted not to pass to Allan Seagar. The Herald mentioned that Brimble's exclusion from the North Island team was unexpected, considering his superior performance compared to Prentice in the trial match.

In the 23 July trial match, Ted Brimble, who was previously overshadowed by Bert Cooke, played as five-eighth for the Possibles team alongside Harry Johns. They won the high-scoring game against the Probables by 37 to 16, with Brimble scoring one of their seven tries. His performance was highlighted by outpacing Claude Dempsey to score a try. Despite Newton, the team Brimble played for, finishing last in the competition, the Star recognized Brimble as the best back on the ground.

In the 23rd of July trial match, Ted Brimble, previously overshadowed by Bert Cooke, showcased his skills as a five-eighth for the Possibles team, scoring a try and outperforming Claude Dempsey. Despite Newton, the team Brimble played for, finishing last in the competition, his exceptional performance was recognized by the Star, highlighting his ability to find gaps, elusiveness, and speed, as well as his strong defense. His performance led to his selection for New Zealand's third test against England, where he played alongside Hec Brisbane and halfback Abbott, in the five-eighth and halfback positions, respectively. The Auckland Star expressed satisfaction with Brimble's inclusion, noting that many judges believed he had been mistakenly overlooked for important matches. In contrast, England's team consisted of Stan Brogden and Bryn Evans.

In the match, Ted Brimble, playing as five-eighth alongside Hec Brisbane and halfback Abbott, displayed strong link-up play and good form, similar to his club football performances. He secured the ball and set up a try for Brisbane. Despite Brimble's efforts, including a try and solid tackling, the Kiwis were on the losing end, with England winning 20-18 due to a last-minute try. The Kiwis were denied an advantage rule opportunity when Cooke mishandled the ball, and Brimble had previously scored a try.

During the match, Ted Brimble had a close call when he nearly allowed a try due to a feint from Bryn Evans, but England was unable to capitalize. A kick by Hec Brisbane caused confusion for the English team, resulting in Cooke scoring a try. However, a potential advantage for the Kiwis was lost when Cooke mishandled the ball. Towards the end of the match, Brimble tried to evade Stan Brogden instead of passing, which led to a mistake and ultimately contributed to New Zealand's 20-18 loss.

In the closing stages of the match, with New Zealand leading by a point, Ted Brimble tried to dodge Stan Brogden instead of passing, leading to a crucial mistake. This allowed Gus Risman to gain possession and initiate a series of passes, resulting in Barney Hudson scoring the winning try. Despite this setback, Brimble was later chosen to represent Auckland in matches against South Auckland and Marist Old Boys. Auckland won the first game, but the Marist side emerged victorious in the charity match for Trevor Hanlon, who needed financial assistance to return from England.

In the match against Marist, Brimble's team lost despite his good performance, which included forming an effective partnership with Crook and Prentice. At the same time, the Manukau rugby league club was reestablished with Ted's brother Lionel as a committee member. Another brother, Walter, would later represent the club's senior side and earn a spot on the New Zealand team. In 1933, Brimble continued to play for Newton, scoring a try in their first game and receiving praise for his performance in subsequent matches. He was particularly noted for his impressive play with Porteous and Barchard.

In the match against City, Brimble had a standout performance, leading Newton to a 16-12 victory. He was praised by the Auckland Star for his brilliance in running, handling, and defending, and by the Herald for his crucial role in attacks. His international experience was highlighted as beneficial. In the third victory against Devonport, Brimble's impressive performance, particularly in the final stages, contributed to their success. His quickness off the mark improved their back movements and passing, according to both newspapers.

In the match against Marist, Brimble had a strong performance despite the team's loss, with his solo try being a highlight. He was instrumental in preventing a try in the first half. However, he faced effective marking by Marist's Hec Brisbane. Brimble's performance against Devonport was also noteworthy, with his quickness enhancing the team's back movements. His form led to his selection for Auckland's match against Taranaki, where he played alongside Dick Smith in the five eighths positions.

In the Auckland vs. Taranaki match, Brimble and Dick Smith formed the five eighths, with Wilf Hassan as halfback and Taranaki having J. Arnold and F. McLaggan in the same positions. Auckland won the game 32-20, with a crowd of 10,000 at Carlaw Park. Brimble had a notable performance, being involved in many attacking movements, but initially struggled with Taranaki's forwards, causing him to drop passes. Later, while playing against City, Brimble collided with his teammate Cameron, resulting in an injury that affected his performance in the second half. He had scored a try in the first half, but the injury forced him to play poorly for the rest of the game.

In the Auckland vs. Taranaki match, Brimble, the five-eighth, had a significant first-half performance, scoring a try by skillfully evading the City backs. However, he later collided with his teammate Cameron, resulting in an injury that negatively impacted his performance in the second half. Both Brimble and Cameron missed the subsequent Newton loss to Devonport. Brimble returned for the 24-8 loss against Marist, where he and Porteous played impressively. Despite initial reports of subpar performance, Brimble showed improvement against Ponsonby, contributing to Newton's 27-15 victory and securing 4th place in the Fox Memorial competition. Brimble was later chosen for a trial match as part of the B Team, which lost the curtain raiser to Auckland v South Auckland on 15 July. He received no specific mention in the match reports.

After the trial match with the B Team, Brimble was selected for the Auckland squad to face Taranaki in New Plymouth, where Auckland won the match. Upon returning to Auckland, Brimble played in five more matches for Newton during the Challenge Round competition, which they won. He was notably mentioned for his significant contributions in their victories over Marist and Devonport, but there were no further reports of his performance due to a possible injury, and he didn't play in Newton's final match against the touring St. George side.

Brimble's performance during the 1934 season had been inconsistent due to a possible injury, causing him to miss matches, including the one against St. George on 11 October. Initially, he struggled with his five-eighth partner, Roy Bright, in Newton's opening game against Richmond, but soon after, he improved significantly, showcasing his brilliance in the subsequent matches, such as the one against Devonport. His notable performance was highlighted during the grandstand opening at Carlaw Park, where he contributed to Newton's victory with his effective work on attack.

Brimble's performance during the 1934 season was inconsistent due to a potential injury, causing him to miss matches. However, he later showed significant improvement, particularly in Newton's victories over Devonport and Marist. His effective work on attack was crucial in these games. Against Ponsonby, Newton suffered a loss due to Porteous's injury, and Brimble, along with Crook and Pope, tried but failed to compensate. Despite this, Brimble's performance was still commendable, as he scored a try and displayed alertness and cleverness. In the match against Richmond, Brimble was instrumental in Newton's near-victory, with his performance being particularly impressive in the context of multiple injuries and ejections on both teams. Overall, Brimble's performance improved as the season progressed, with his work at five-eighth being a significant factor in Newton's victories.

Brimble's performance significantly improved throughout the 1934 season, despite his injury, which caused him to miss some matches. His work as a five-eighth was crucial in Newton's victories, as seen in their wins over Devonport and Marist. Injuries and ejections affected both teams during the match against Richmond, but Brimble still played well. McNeil, Ted Mincham, Ray Lawless, and Reuban Kelsall were all injured or ejected during the first half of a game. Brimble's performance was highly regarded, and his son, Owen Stephens, later represented both New Zealand and Australia in rugby union and played for Parramatta and Wakefield Trinity in rugby league. Brimble received an insurance payout for breaking his collarbone, which suggests he was injured during a game. He missed matches against City, Devonport, and Ponsonby but returned to play against Marist, with Roy Hardgrave, a New Zealand international, on the wing for Newton.

Newton emerged victorious in their matches against Marist and Richmond, with Roy Hardgrave's return and Brimble's impressive performance contributing to their success. Despite missing some games due to injury, Brimble excelled in his role as five-eighth, showcasing his elusive running, fine supporting play, and clever work on both attack and defense. His performance against Marist was particularly noteworthy, as he was instrumental in Newton's narrow 9-8 win. The Herald praised Brimble for his nippy and penetrating runs, which often created gaps in the opposing team's defense.

After helping Newton win against Marist and Richmond, Brimble's notable performance as five-eighth continued, despite missing a game due to influenza. His nippy and penetrating runs often created opportunities, as seen when he scored a try against Marist. Playing for Auckland alongside Brian Riley and Vincent Axmann, Brimble contributed to their victory over Northland. The Herald noted his effective defense against their opponent's five-eighth, Ted Meyer. Brimble's performance that season led to him playing several more games for Newton.

In the Roope Rooster tournament, Newton, including Brimble, got eliminated in the first round by City but proceeded to win the Phelan Shield's inaugural season, a consolation knockout competition. Brimble and Cameron stood out in the final, with Brimble scoring one of the four tries. This victory allowed Newton to advance to the Stormont Shield final against Richmond. Brimble served as a reserve for Auckland against South Auckland but did not play. Later, the Western Suburbs club from Sydney visited Auckland for five club matches in September-October.

In September-October, the Western Suburbs club from Sydney, who were the New South Wales champions, visited Auckland for five club matches. One of these matches was against Newton, where Brimble and Cameron played well together, harassing their opponents with their quick starts, but their collaborative work on attack was less impressive. The match ended in a 10-10 draw. Brimble scored Newton's only try in their last match of the season, the Stormont Shield final against Richmond, but Richmond won easily. The Auckland Star praised Brimble's performance, noting that he played his best club game to date, but was let down by some poor handling. Additionally, Brother joined Brimble at Newton and Auckland for a southern tour.

In the 1934 season, Wilfred "Bunny" Brimble transferred from Manukau third intermediate to the Newton seniors, joined by his brother Ted. They displayed promising form in the preseason and made their debut in Newton's first match against Richmond. Wilfred, playing as halfback, showcased impressive skills, while Ted, at five-eighths, was dangerous on attack but had some defensive lapses. The Brimble brothers frequently broke through the defense, though Richmond won the match. Wilfred's performance was praised as his best club game, but poor handling affected some of his efforts. The brothers later embarked on a southern tour with Auckland.

In the 1934 season, Wilfred "Bunny" Brimble, playing as a halfback, and his brother Ted, at five-eighths, demonstrated strong offensive skills and frequently broke through the opposing team's defense in their matches for the Newton seniors. Wilfred's play was marked by clean passing and clever running, while Ted was dangerous in attack. They had a particularly successful game against Mount Albert, where Wilfred scored two tries and Ted was praised as the best back. Wilfred's performance in this game and others was highly regarded, with his partnership with Ted being a highlight. Wilfred also showcased his kicking abilities, scoring three goals in a match against Marist. The brothers' skills were further highlighted during their southern tour with Auckland.

In the 1934 season, Wilfred and Ted Brimble, playing as halfback and five-eighths respectively, were crucial to Newton Seniors' offense. They often breached the opposing team's defense, with Wilfred's game characterized by clean passing, clever running, and effective kicking, while Ted was dangerous in attack. Their exceptional performance against Mount Albert, where Wilfred scored two tries and Ted was lauded as the best back, was a standout. The brothers' skills were particularly highlighted during their southern tour with Auckland. In a match against Marist, Wilfred scored a try and kicked three goals, while Ted scored another try. Their quickness, accurate passing, and combination were instrumental in Newton's success, as they "constituted the mainspring of attack" and gave Marist a hard time. The "fine combination" between the brothers was a notable aspect of their game, serving as an example for other inside backs in Auckland. Wilfred's try against City in round 7 was described as the gem of the match, contributing to Newton's 15–5 victory.

In the 1934 season, Wilfred and Ted Brimble, playing as halfback and five-eighths respectively, were instrumental to Newton Seniors' offense. They worked well together, showcasing quickness, accurate passing, and effective attacking skills. Their combination was particularly evident in a match against Ponsonby, where Ted set up a try for Maurice Quirke in the final moments, securing a 14-13 victory for Newton. Ted's performance was notable, being described as the best back on the ground and creating several scoring opportunities for his teammates. The match was significant as it was the first ever played at the Glen Eden Recreation round, home of the Glenora Bears rugby league club.

In the 1934 season, Ted Brimble, playing as five-eighths, significantly contributed to Newton Seniors' success. He and his halfback brother, Wilfred, formed a strong combination, showcasing quickness and accurate passing. This partnership was evident in their match against Ponsonby, where Ted set up a try for Maurice Quirke, securing a 14-13 victory. Ted's performance was praised, being described as the best back on the ground. However, he was criticized for being selfish in another match. Despite this, he was named in the Auckland B side but ended up playing in the Auckland A side against Taranaki, where he performed better in the second half. Newton Seniors finished 4th in the championship. The matches were significant as they were the first ever played at the Glen Eden Recreation round, home of the Glenora Bears rugby league club.

In the 1934 season, Ted Brimble, playing as five-eighths, significantly contributed to Newton Seniors' success. He and his halfback brother, Wilfred, had a strong combination, displaying quickness and accurate passing. Ted's individual skills were highlighted as he scored three tries on his own.
